STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
November 8, 2021
Renee Adorjan
Washtenaw County DHHS
22 Center St.
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
RE: License #: CP810201490
Washtenaw County DHHS
22 Center St.
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
Dear Mrs. Adorjan:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on (date). Due
to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Implementation
Sustainability and Exit Plan (ISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the
ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 860-0787.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP810201490
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Washtenaw County DHHS
Facility Address: 22 Center St.
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
Facility Telephone #: (734) 481-8364
Original Issuance Date: 10/05/1994
Service Types:
1

Date of On-site Inspection(s): 10/11/2021-10/13/2021 10/18/2021 & 10/25/2021

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
Four of 10 employee records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record showed the employee’s six month’s
performance evaluation due by 9/21/2021 was completed
eight days late on 9/29/2021.
 A second record did not show documentation of a 2021
annual performance evaluation due by 9/2/2021 per the
last one documented.
 A third record did not show documentation of annual
evaluation due by 12/19/2020, per the last one completed
dated 12/19/2019.
 A fourth record did not show documentation of the
employee’s six-month evaluation due by 6/1/2020,
related the employee’s current position on 12/1/2019.
R 400.12306 Application request.
(1) An agency shall provide an orientation for prospective
applicants for a foster home license before a foster home
application is provided.
Two of three enrolled foster home records reviewed did not
show documentation of the applicant’s orientation.
R 400.12306 Application request.
(3) An agency shall document that a person who has met the
requirements of subrule (1) of this rule has received an
application and information regarding all of the following:
(a) A copy of the act.
(b) Administrative rules for foster homes.
(c) Administrative rules for child placing agencies.
4

(d) Good moral character rules.
(e)The child protection law.
(f) The children’s ombudsman act.
Two of three enrolled foster home records reviewed did not
show documentation that (a)-(f) was provided.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
One of six open foster home records reviewed did not show
compliance to the rule. The Renewal home visit was completed
12/14/2020 for the license expiring 12/22/2020.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2020.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received orientation
to the policies of the borrowing agency.
(g) A copy of the foster parent/agency agreement signed by the
foster parent and the borrowing agency.
One of three borrowed home records reviewed did not showed
documentation of compliance:
 The foster parent signed the agency’s policies and
procedures and foster parent agency agreement on
9/21/2021; more than a month after the child’s 8/3/2021
placement effective date.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons interviewed,
and names of the interviewers. If children are interviewed, their
last names shall not be included in the report.
(e) Findings of fac, based upon the evaluation.
5

(d):
Two of four special evaluations reviewed did not clearly indicate
the interviewer for all interviews.
(e):
Two of four special evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation of an analysis of findings based on interviews,
so as to indicate that the home remains incompliance.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
Four of four special evaluation records reviewed did not show
documentation that a copy of the report was provided the
worker.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed corrective
action plan, all social services workers who have children
placed in the home shall be notified there is a corrective action
and what is required of the foster parent in that plan.
Two of four special evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation of (7), as required by the rule.
MCL 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of conditions,
books, records, and reports; access by department, bureau
of fire services, or local authorities; records; report; forms;
confidentiality; disclosure of information; availability of
confidential records; child information cards to be provided
to department; failure of licensee to cooperate with
investigation, inspection, or examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care and
shall report to the department, when requested, the facts
the department requires with reference to the children upon
forms furnished by the department. Except as otherwise
provided in this subsection and subsection (4), records
regarding children and facts compiled about children and
their parents and relatives are confidential and disclosure
of this information shall be properly safeguarded by the
6

childcare organization, the department, and any other entity
in possession of the information. Records that are
confidential under this section are available to both of the
following:
Two of four special evaluations reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record listed the children’s full names in the report,
and documented children protective services language.
 A second record listed the children’s and the birth
parent’s full names in the report, documented children
protective services language and children protective
services involvement in the report.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
The agency’s medical and dental policy shall, at a minimum,
include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical examination
shall have been completed within 12 months before placement
or a new physical examination shall be completed within 30
calendar days after placement.
One of four open foster child records reviewed showed the
child’s physical examinations due by 2/21/2021 was completed
16 days late on 3/9/2021.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
(a):
One of three initial service plans (ISP) reviewed was completed
six days late.
(b):
Three of 17 updated service plans (USP) reviewed were not in
compliance:
 One child’s 9/4/2020-12/2/2020 USP was completed one
day late on 12/3/2020.
7

 A second child’s 1/15/2021-4/14/2021 USP was
completed one day late on 4/15/2021. This child’s
4/15/2021- 7/13/2021 USP was completed seven days
late on 7/20/2021.
R 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service pan, as required in R400.12418(2)(a),
shall include all of the following information:
(c)Assessment of the placement selection criteria as required
under R400.12404(4).
One of three ISPs reviewed did not show documentation of (c),
as required by the rule.
R 400. 12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R 400.418(2)(b),
shall include all of the following information:
(g) A child management plan which includes any changes made
since the previous plan and which is to be used by the foster
parents.
Two of 17 updated service plans reviewed did not show
documentation of the specific behavior management plan to be
used by the foster parent for that child.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least every 90 calendar days and a copy provided to
the youth.
Two of three independent living records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record did not show documentation of a March or
June 2021 contract.
 A second record did not show documentation of a May
2021 contract.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MSA violation. Please note that there
are additional MSA requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional MSA requirements except for the following:
8

ISEP 4.22 MISACWIS (Commitment 22).
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the
primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
In various open foster care and independent living youth
records reviewed, the record did not show uploads of all
required documents. Various documents were provided at exit
(i.e., signed parent agency treatment plan agreements, signed
service plans, budgetary documents, signed independent living
contracts or FTM forms).
ISEP 6.33 Assessment and Service Plans, Content (Commitment 69).
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
One of 20 service plans reviewed did not show documentation
of the youth’s signature.
ISEP 6.49 Medical passports. (Commitment 85).
(a) At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care
provider shall receive the child’s Medical Passport, which must
contain the information required by MCL 722.954c(2) and DHHS
Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any successor policies
approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly thereafter, and
updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by the
“Medical Passports” section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-
1-2015) (or any successor policy approved by the Monitors) and
provided to the foster care provider.
In one of four open foster child records reviewed, the record did
not show clear, consistent documentation of quarterly medical
passports. Signature pages were documented for 4/27/2021,
5/6/2021 and 9/14/2021 but I could not discern when a medical
passport was completed for the said signature page. A medical
passport was not documented for December 2020, or March
2021.
9

Repeat Violation- Interim 2019, cited under policy 801.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
Policy FOM 722- Family team meeting.
6B
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as out lined in the following table.
Three of four open foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record did not show documentation of an FTM for
the child’s 12/5/2020-3/2/2021 USP. A FTM was
completed earlier than required on 1/27/2021.
 A second record did not show documentation of an FTM
for the child’s 2/17/2021-5/17/2021 USP. A FTM was
completed earlier than required on 3/25/2021.
Additionally, this child’s record did not show
documentation of a DHS-1105 for an indicated FTM on
2/16/2021, 3/25/2021 and 8/13/2021.
 A third record did not show documentation of a FTM for
the child’s 9/4/2020-12/2/2020 USP. A FTM was
completed earlier then required on10/30/2020.
Additionally, this child’s record did not show
documentation of an FTM for the child’s 12/3/2020-
3/1/2021 USP. A FTM was completed after the period on
3/4/2021. The record also did not show documentation of
a DHS-1105 for a 5/21/2021 indicated FTM.
10

Policy FOM 722- Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
8C Agreement.
Signature: When completed, obtain all signatures as
appropriate, including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14
and older and in the case of placement agency foster care
cases, the local DHS office designee
Of 20 service plans reviewed, one did not contain the foster
parent/caregiver’s signature.
Policy FOM 722- Foster care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
8E
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
MISACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
action/change:
Case Closure/ Change in placement:
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure or a placement change.
In one of three closed independent youth records reviewed the
record did not show documentation of a DHS-69 for the youth’s
case closure.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12324(2)(b) Reevaluation.
 The agency is apprised it shall clearly and consistently document the worker’s
assessment of the foster parent’s strengths and weaknesses.
R400.12326(1) (c)(d) Borrowed home.
 The agency is apprised documentation of its endorsement of the certifying
agency’ evaluations shall be clearly verifiable.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
None this inspection.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
11

There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The incident related to allegations that the foster parent’s 18-year-old special needs
adopted daughter choked the foster parent’s five-year-old adopted son, while the
foster parent was at the store. During the investigation the foster parent admitted to
not being home at the time of the incident. Additionally, it was revealed the foster
parent did not have an appropriate substitute care provider; was transporting one of
the foster children in the front car seat in a booster seat as opposed to a required car
seat; was not dropping off or picking the foster children up from day care at times
that were within appropriate time parameters; and was not providing/conducting
adequate hygiene for the children prior to dropping the foster children off for day
care. Also, that the foster parent and her daughter were referring to the foster
children(twins) who are temporary court wards by names other than their birth
names. Rule noncompliance were found related to behavior management and the
indicated issues. The foster children were replaced from the home and revocation of
the foster parent’s license was recommended.
The agency adhered to departmental timeframe and standards related to this
incident.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The corrective action plan related to the agency’s Renewal Inspection, at which time
the agency received the following citations:
 R400.12324(8) For reevaluation.
 R400.12326(1)(a) for Borrowed home.
 R400.12413(1)(c) for Medical and dental policy, related to a well child
examination.
 R400.12413(1) (c) for Medical and dental policy, related to updated
immunizations.
 R400.12413(1)(f) for Medical and dental policy, related to a child’s dental
examination.
 R400.12418(6) for Development of service plans and plans not being
signed by the social service worker and social service supervisor.
 R400.12507 Medical/dental and mental health care, pertaining to overdue
immunizations for youths.
The agency made progress with their corrective action plan but were not
completely successful with it. The agency received a repeat violation this
inspection related to R400.12324(8) and R400.12413(1)(c).
12

DCWL ANALYST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
There were no safety alerts this inspection.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
November 6, 2021
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
November 8, 2021
________________________________________
Linda D. Tansil Date
Area Manager
